name: OKTA [MFA Bypass Attempted]
description: Okta detected an attempt to bypass a factor of authentication. Review other events by this user around this timeframe for signs of compromise.

name: OKTA [Multiple Lockouts From One Source]
description: Several account lockouts were detected from one source IP. This could be an indication of an attack.
Tags: Trellix Cloud, Trellix Atomic, Trellix Network Artifact

name: OKTA [Logon Failure From Tor]
description: A logon failure from a Tor exit node was detected. This may be normal activity depending on your organization's remote access policy.
Tags: Trellix Cloud, Trellix Atomic, Trellix Network Artifact

name: OKTA [Logon From Tor]
description: A successful logon from a Tor exit node was detected. This may be legitimate depending on your organization's remote access policy.
Tags: Trellix Cloud, Trellix Atomic, Trellix User Behavior

name: OKTA [MFA Deactivated]
description: A factor of authentication was deactivated. This could be normal business activity, or the result of an attacker downgrading security mechanisms on a compromised account.

name: OKTA [Admin Privilege Granted]
description: Detects the Okta adminstrator privileges assigned to non-admin user accounts/group. This could be a normal business activity, hence the analysts are advised to tune the rule for known admin accounts and privilege levels (privlevel).
query: class=okta eventtype:[`user.account.privilege.grant`,`group.privilege.grant`] NOT privlevel:`super administrator` NOT srcipv4:$exclusions.global.srcipv4

name: OKTA [MFA Reset]
description: All authentication factors were reset for a user.

name: OKTA [Zone Update]
description: An IP zone update was made. Depending on your organization's policy, this change could affect if users get challenged. Review the IP range in the raw log to determine if it's legitimate.

name: OKTA [Super Administrator Privilege Granted]
description: A "super administrator" privilege has been granted to a user.
query: class=okta eventtype=user.account.privilege.grant privlevel:`super administrator` NOT srcipv4:$exclusions.global.srcipv4

name: OKTA [Multiple MFA Failures]
description: Multiple MFA failures were detected for a user. This could be an indicator of an attack on that account. Check other logs for this user around the same timeframe for other indicators of attack.
Tags: Trellix Cloud, Trellix Atomic, Trellix User Behavior

name: OKTA [User Enumeration]
description: This rule looks for several "unknown user" failures from one source within a short time period. This could indicate user enumeration reconnaissance activity.
query: class=okta eventtype=user.session.start reason=[`unknown user`,`unknown_user`] NOT srcipv4:$exclusions.global.srcipv4
Tags: Trellix Cloud, Trellix Atomic, Trellix User Behavior

name: OKTA [Threat Detected]
description: Okta detected a security threat. Details can be found in the raw log.

name: OKTA [User Impersonation]
description: This rule looks for any user impersonation attempts observed in the environment. This activity is unlikely to be performed, unless it is for the business. Check the legitimacy of the activity.

name: OKTA [Suspicious Activity Reported By User]
description: This rule looks for a "user.account.report_suspicious_activity_by_enduser" event in Okta logs. Generally, only Okta users report suspicious activity. If this rule triggers an alert for other users, those users could have escalated privileges and could be performing unauthorized activity.

name: OKTA [Policy Rule Modified]
description: This alert triggers off of the "policy.rule.delete", "policy.rule.update", "policy.rule.deactivate" or "policy.rule.invalidate" events from Okta. This would indicate a modification to the security policies applied to your Okta environment. This could be legitimate activity done by an authorized admin however it should be verified.

name: OKTA [Application Modified]
description: This alert triggers off of the "application.lifecycle.update" or "application.lifecycle.delete" events from Okta. These events will trigger on modification or deletion of apps within your Okta environment. This activity should only be done by authorized admins.

name: OKTA [Application Sign On Policy Modified]
description: This alert triggers off of "application.policy.sign_on.update" or "application.policy.sign_on.rule.delete" event from the Okta logs. An adversary may attempt to modify or remove these policies to weaken or remove your security controls. If there are policies that are regularly modified they should be excluded.

name: OKTA [Possible DOS]
description: This event triggers off of rate limit violation events from Okta. This could indicate an adversary attempting the DOS attack your Okta environment to cause an impact to normal business functions.

name: OKTA [Phishing Detected via FastPass]
description: This rule looks for the adversary-in-the-middle(AiTM) phishing attempt activity, observed by the Okta's Passwordless solution known as FastPass.
query: class=okta eventtype=user.authentication.auth_via_mfa result=failure reason:`fastPass declined phishing attempt` NOT srcipv4:$exclusions.global.srcipv4

name: OKTA [New Behavior Detected on Admin Console]
description: This rule looks for change in the behavior of any user accessing the Okta Admin Console. This change is detected as per the Okta's behavior detection system. Refer the infoLinks given for more details.
query: class=okta eventtype=policy.evaluate_sign_on has(behavior) target=`okta admin console` NOT srcipv4:$exclusions.global.srcipv4

name: OKTA [Identity Provider Created]
description: This rule looks for the successful creation of an Identity Provider. Identity Providers(IdP) are services that manage user accounts in Okta. Adding IdPs may enable the end users to self-register with their custom applications. More details can be found in the infoLinks given.

name: OKTA [Sign-In Attempts Via Anonymous Proxy Servers]
description: This rule looks for sign in attempts made by a user using anonymous proxy servers. This change is detected as per the Okta's behavior detection system. Refer the infoLinks given for more details.
